TreeScapeModel

The TreeScape Model lets you define what you want to see in your charts. You can specify x axis and annotations.

class TreeScapeModel.TreeScapeModel(th_ens, profiles)

Bases: object

get_PJ_bus()

For internal use. The PJ bus allows Python variables to be sent down to the javascript layer.

Returns

An object containing the things required for plotting.

setGroupBy(group_by: str)

You can set the group by of the stacked line chart you want to see. This will create multiple charts. Each chart use value of the group by parameter. For example, if jobsize is selected, the first plot will only show jobsize = 4, the second plot might use jobsize = 13, etc.

Parameters

xaxis_name – examples are jobsize, problem_size, launchdate, etc.

Returns

setVisibleAnnotations(nameOfLinesToPlot)

You can set the names of the lines you wish to plot

Parameters

nameOfLinesToPlot – provide an array of annotation (str) you wish to plot

Returns

setXAggregation(aggregation: str)

This determines how multiple values are aggregated

Parameters

aggregation – examples are sum, max, min, average.

Returns

setXAxis(xaxis_name: str)

You can set the X axis of the stacked line chart you want to see. The name given must be present as an attribute in the meta dataset.

Parameters

xaxis_name – examples are jobsize, problem_size, launchdate, etc.

Returns

setYAxis(yaxis_name: str)

You can set the Y axis of the stacked line chart you want to see. the name given must be present as an attribute in the meta dataset.

Parameters

yaxis_name –

Returns

This is an example of how to set visible annotations. The annotations given are from the lulesh gen data set. .. code-block:: python

model.setVisibleAnnotations([‘CalcLagrangeElements’, ‘CalcQForElems’, ‘ApplyMaterialPropertiesForElems’])
